docs.lead_paragraph: More than half of privately insured women are getting free birth control under President Barack Obama's health law, a major coverage shift that's likely to advance.

headline.main: Free Birth Control Is Emerging Standard for Women
headline.print_headline: Free Birth Control Is Emerging Standard for Women

docs.lead_paragraph: The 5-year-old U.S. recovery is gaining momentum from a surprisingly robust job market and moving the economy closer to full health.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Illinois Supreme Court on Thursday sided with retired state employees who argue that health insurance coverage is a constitutionally protected retirement benefit.

headline.main: Illinois: Court Rules for Retirees in Benefits Suit
headline.print_headline: Illinois: Court Rules for Retirees in Benefits Suit

docs.abstract: Illinois Supreme Court sides with retired state employees who argued that health insurance coverage is constitutionally protected retirement benefit; 6-to-1 ruling reverses lower court decision that allowed state to require retirees to pay for part of their health care.
docs.snippet: The Illinois Supreme Court on Thursday sided with retired state employees who argue that health insurance coverage is a constitutionally protected retirement benefit.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court temporarily barred the government from enforcing against a Christian college a contraception rule under the Affordable Care Act, drawing a furious dissent from the three female justices, who said the court had broken a promise.

headline.main: Birth Control Order Deepens Divide Among Justices
headline.print_headline: Birth Control Deepens Divide Among Justices

docs.abstract: Supreme Court sides 5-to-4 with religiously affiliated nonprofit groups in clash between religious freedom and women's rights; decision, which prompts furious dissent from Justices Sonia Sotomayor, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Elena Kagan, temporarily exempts Wheaton College from part of regulations that provide contraceptive coverage under Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court temporarily barred the government from enforcing against a Christian college a contraception rule under the Affordable Care Act, drawing a furious dissent from the three female justices, who said the court had broken a promise.

headline.main: At a YMCA Near You, a Course for a Diabetic Nation

docs.abstract: Eighty percent of Americans live within five miles of a YMCA. How can that help slow the nation’s diabetes epidemic?
docs.snippet: Eighty percent of Americans live within five miles of a YMCA. How can that help slow the nation’s diabetes epidemic?

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court gave a Christian college in Illinois a temporary exemption from birth control coverage required by President Barack Obama's health reform law, days after ruling that for-profit employers can opt out for religious reasons.

headline.main: College Wins U.S. Top Court Temporary Exemption on Obamacare Birth Control

headline.main: Stroke Lessons (Time Wasted is Brain Lost)

docs.abstract: Three years after a lucky stroke, a reminder about the importance of speedy diagnosis and care.
docs.snippet: Three years after a lucky stroke, a reminder about the importance of speedy diagnosis and care.

docs.lead_paragraph: A divided Supreme Court on Thursday allowed, at least for now, an evangelical college in Illinois that objects to paying for contraceptives in its health plan to avoid filling out a government document that the college says would violate its religious beliefs.

headline.main: The Surprise in the Hobby Lobby Comments

docs.abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to allow corporations to opt out of including contraception in mandated health care coverage drew over 4,000 reader comments this week.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court’s decision to allow corporations to opt out of including contraception in mandated health care coverage drew over 4,000 reader comments this week.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Seattle business group has submitted signatures to try to force a public vote to repeal a municipal measure that would raise the city's minimum wage to $15 an hour, a leader of the organization said on Thursday.

headline.main: Measure to Repeal Seattle $15 Minimum Wage Moves Closer to Ballot
headline.print_headline: Measure to Repeal Seattle $15 Minimum Wage Moves Closer to Ballot

docs.snippet: A Seattle business group has submitted signatures to try to force a public vote to repeal a municipal measure that would raise the city's minimum wage to $15 an hour, a leader of the organization said on Thursday.
